Author: I wrote this to answer someone who was looking for a run-down on Peak. I'm reposting it here so everyone can see and hopefully it answers questions for anyone wondering what Peak is all about. (All the info below is from their website and CEO interviews/presentations)So Peak is a Canadian company which owns a bunch of subsidiaries that operate in the Chinese commercial lending industry centered around a fintech product called the Cubeler Lending Hub.Here are the basics:1)The lending hub pre-qualifies businesses that are looking for business financing and connects them with banks/lending institutions. When there is a match and a loan is provided Cubeler charges a fee. Imagine it exactly like Tindr but for people looking for money.2)Peak also has the ability to facilitate transactions between factories
RelativeDate: manufacturers and small businesses. So let's say you are a pre-qualified business on the Lending Hub. For example
Likes: a home builder. You are waiting to buy new lumber but can't afford to buy it until one of your clients pays you. Through the Lending Hub
Dislikes: Peak can now loan you the funds so you can order your lumber. Peak will facilitate the transaction and settle the account once the client pays up.3)Another major recent development is that Peak will now earn daily interest on the funds in its "float". Meaning all the money in Peak's accounts waiting to be sent here and there will earn interest every 24 hours at approx 2% per annum. That will be 2% of billions every year.4)Peak currently operates in 12 cities and is expanding quickly with plans of starting up in India as early as this year.5)Peak is working towards a deal this year with the large e-commerce giants in China to provide their lending hub services through one or more of the e-commerce platforms. It's not guaranteed to happen yet

Content: PEAK FINTECH DUE DILIGENCE AND PRICE TARGET.Hi Everyone! I have been investing in Peak for a few weeks (I am at 39k share currently) and I am long on this one. I initially didn't do much research except for some light reading but was really sold by the CEO's presentation on WSR. Well
Author: I suddenly realized how insane it is that I invested so much without doing better research so I decided to figure out a price target given currently available information in anticipation of Q4 earnings. I can't tell you how pleased I am with what I found. Here is the info. PLEASE correct any errors you might see
RelativeDate: but I think Peak is currently a $11.35 stock trading for $2.9 and here is why:-Peak's revenue for all of 2019 was $11.7M. In the first quarter of 2020 Peak made $3.9M. Second quarter 2020: $7.26M. Third quarter 2020: $15.1M. So for the first 3 quarters of 2020 Peak made $26.3M (already more than double all of 2019).If Peak simply maintains their Q3 2020 earnings for Q4 2020 then their annual revenue for 2020 will be $41.4M. That means with a BACKWARDS looking revenue multiple of 10x Peak should be valued at a $410M market cap. According to Yahoo Finance the current market cap is $281M. That would mean the current share price should be $4.23 once Q4 gets released (assuming 0 growth for Q4).-Now
Likes: let's say they maintain $15M in revenue per quarter for a full year. That would mean $60M in revenue for 2021. At a 10x forward looking multiple the market cap should be approx $600M. That means the share price today should be approx $6.19.-Now
Dislikes: Peak announced a major revenue stream about a month ago. They now have the ability to charge interest on the entirety of their float used to facilitate transactions between their clients at a rate of 2%. The company has not released numbers yet BUT the CEO did say they had approx $1B in funds that traveled through their float in 2019. So if we did a very rough estimate and said that if they held $1B throughout 2019 which resulted in revenue of $11.7M then their float will be approximately $5.1B for 2021 with $60M in revenue. The 2% fees they will collect will begin halfway through 2021 so 2% of $5.1B for half a year is $51M in revenue. Add that to the $60M then you can estimate 2021 revenue at $110M. At 10x forward revenue we are looking at a $1.1B market cap and share price of $11.35 today. Now
column8: I only applied their service fee to half the year. For 2022 they will have a full year of 2% fees- so $102M in revenue from that stream alone ($162M combined).Now
column9: I am sure you noticed something. All of this assumes zero growth. These numbers are just if they MAINTAIN their Q3 2020 revenue while adding their float fee. Yet

column15: if NASDAQ investors value the company by estimated 2024 revenue at a higher revenue multiple like they do for most companies- we might be looking at a truly sky high share price this year. Please give me your thoughts.More

RelativeDate: it's the whole damn pizzeria. So chill. Why are people concerned about a reverse-split generally? Companies that have a share price trajectory going DOWN that have to maintain a minimum price to remain on certain exchanges might reverse split to meet minimum share price requirements. So a reverse split under that circumstance sends the signal that the company is having trouble attracting investors. In PKK's case the current price trajectory is UP
Likes: not down. And to speed things up
Dislikes: they are consolidating the shares. What is the net benefit? We will be on the NASDAQ. A Canadian FINTECH company serving the enormous Chinese commercial lending space will get irrational amounts of attention on the NASDAQ. So it's a win-win all around as a result of the reverse split. Context matters. Big money
